title: Machine Knitting vs Hand Knitting: Which Is Right for You?
author: Sue Jalowiec
excerpt: Thinking about trying machine knitting? Here's an honest comparison to help you decide if it's the right choice for your knitting goals.
description: Thinking about trying machine knitting? Here's an honest comparison to help you decide if it's the right choice for your knitting goals.
body:
I'm often asked: "Should I learn machine knitting or stick with hand knitting?" The truth is, they're different tools for different goals—and many knitters enjoy both.

Speed: The Obvious Difference

Let's address the elephant in the room: machine knitting is dramatically faster.

  • Hand knitting: 20-40 stitches per minute (for an experienced knitter)
  • Machine knitting: 200-400 stitches per minute

A hand-knit sweater might take 40-60 hours. The same sweater on a machine? 4-8 hours of actual knitting time (plus setup, finishing, and seaming).

What Machine Knitting Does Better

1. Large Projects

Sweaters, blankets, and garments are where machines shine. You can knit a full sweater body in an afternoon rather than weeks of hand knitting.

2. Consistent Tension

The machine handles tension mechanically, so every stitch is identical. No more wonky gauge changes halfway through a project.

3. Production Work

Making multiples? (Baby blankets for gifts, hats for a craft fair, matching family sweaters?) Machines excel at repetitive production.

4. Fine Gauge Fabrics

Machines can knit lace-weight and fingering yarns into delicate, even fabrics that would take forever by hand.

What Hand Knitting Does Better

1. Portability

Hand knitting fits in your bag. Machine knitting requires a dedicated workspace and a table that can support 15-40 pounds of equipment.

2. Complex Shaping

Increases, decreases, and short rows are natural with needles in your hands. On a machine, they require more planning and technique.

3. Small Projects

A hand-knit dishcloth takes 20 minutes. Setting up a machine, knitting the same dishcloth, and cleaning up? Also about 20 minutes. Hand knitting wins for tiny projects.

4. Textured Stitches

Cables, bobbles, and complex stitch patterns are much easier by hand. While machines can create texture, it often requires manual manipulation.

5. Meditative Process

Many hand knitters love the rhythmic, meditative quality of the craft. Machine knitting is more technical and less "zen."

The Learning Curve

Here's an unpopular truth: machine knitting is harder to learn than hand knitting.

Hand knitting has two basic stitches (knit and purl) and you can start making scarves your first day. Machine knitting requires:

  • Understanding mechanical systems
  • Learning tension adjustments
  • Troubleshooting when things jam or drop
  • Reading punch cards or programming patterns
  • Manual finishing and seaming skills

Expect 20-40 hours of practice before you're comfortable, and 100+ hours before you're proficient.

Cost Considerations

Hand Knitting Startup:

  • Needles: $10-50
  • Yarn for first project: $20-50
  • Total: $30-100

Machine Knitting Startup:

  • Used machine: $200-800
  • Accessories (latch tools, weights, yarn, etc.): $100-200
  • Learning resources: $50-200
  • Total: $350-1,200

Machine knitting requires significant upfront investment, though the per-project cost decreases dramatically once you own the equipment.

Which Should You Choose?

Choose Hand Knitting If:

  • You enjoy the slow, meditative process
  • You want maximum portability
  • You love complex cables and texture
  • You're on a tight budget
  • You prefer small, quick projects

Choose Machine Knitting If:

  • You want to make garments quickly
  • You're interested in the technical/mechanical side
  • You plan to make multiples (gifts, sales, family items)
  • You have dedicated workspace
  • You find hand knitting too slow for your goals

Choose Both If:

  • You want the best of both worlds!
  • You can use the machine for sweater bodies and hand knit details
  • You like variety in your making

My Recommendation

If you're curious about machine knitting, I recommend learning basic hand knitting first. Understanding stitch structure, increases, decreases, and finishing will make machine knitting much easier to learn.

Then, if you find yourself thinking "I wish I could knit this faster" while working on sweaters or blankets, that's your sign that a knitting machine might be right for you.

Both forms of knitting are valid, valuable, and wonderful. Choose the one that serves your goals—or embrace them both!
